evidence.text: Defendant’s uses of the CEB have disproportionately excluded African-American applicants from employment in these positions

evidence.text: Since at least 2015, DFD has used a multi-step selection process to select entry-level firefighters.

extracted.value: Since at least 2015, DFD has used a multi-step selection process to select entry-level firefighters.

evidence.text: Among other screening devices, this multi-step selection process has included the use of scores from a written test.

extracted.value: The multi-step selection process has included the use of scores from a written test.

evidence.text: At the outset of the selection process, Defendant screens all applicants.

extracted.value: At the outset of the selection process, Defendant screens all applicants.

evidence.text: Those applicants who fail to meet a set of minimum qualifications do not advance further in the multi-step selection process and are not hired as DFD entry-level firefighters.

extracted.value: Applicants who fail to meet a set of minimum qualifications do not advance further in the multi-step selection process and are not hired as DFD entry-level firefighters.

evidence.text: To advance in the selection process after meeting the minimum qualifications, applicants for DFD’s entry-level firefighter positions must successfully obtain a passing score on a multiple-choice written test.

extracted.value: Applicants must successfully obtain a passing score on a multiple-choice written test to advance.

evidence.text: DFD conducts in-person interviews of applicants during the multi-step selection process.

extracted.value: DFD conducts in-person interviews of applicants during the multi-step selection process.

evidence.text: To reach the in-person interview step of the selection process, an applicant must first obtain a passing score on the written test.

extracted.value: To reach the in-person interview step, an applicant must first obtain a passing score on the written test.

evidence.text: Since October 2015, Defendant has administered and used the CEB, which was developed by Fire and Police Selection, Inc. (“FPSI”), a consulting firm that, among other things, provides firefighter testing products to screen applicants for entry-level firefighter positions.

extracted.value: Since October 2015, Defendant has administered and used the CEB, developed by FPSI.

evidence.text: The CEB consists of five sections: reading (15 questions), math (20 questions), writing (20 questions), map reading (15 questions), and interpersonal competency/human relations (30 questions). All 100 questions are multiple choice.

extracted.value: The CEB consists of five sections: reading (15 questions), math (20 questions), writing (20 questions), map reading (15 questions), and interpersonal competency/human relations (30 questions). All 100 questions are multiple choice.

evidence.text: From 2015 to 2017, the written test included an additional section called the Practical Skills Test (“PST”), also developed by FPSI.

extracted.value: From 2015 to 2017, the written test included an additional section called the Practical Skills Test (PST).

evidence.text: Since 2019, the written test has not included the PST, and the CEB has constituted the entire written test administered to applicants.

extracted.value: Since 2019, the written test has not included the PST.

evidence.text: Since 2015, applicants for entry-level firefighter positions who have scored less than 70% on the written test have not advanced further in Defendant’s multi-step selection process.

extracted.value: Since 2015, applicants who scored less than 70% on the written test have not advanced further.

evidence.text: Since 2015, Defendant has ranked applicants for entry-level firefighter positions who are eligible for an interview in the order of their overall numerical scores on the written test.

extracted.value: Since 2015, Defendant has ranked applicants for interview in order of overall scores.

evidence.text: African-American applicants who took the written test (“test-takers”) failed the written test at a higher rate than white test-takers. Approximately 37% of African-American test-takers failed the written test, and approximately 11% of white test-takers failed.

extracted.value: African-American applicants who took the written test failed at a higher rate than white applicants.

evidence.text: During this time period, the difference between the pass rates of African-American and white test-takers on the written test is statistically significant, with a standard deviation of more than three units.

extracted.value: The difference between pass rates is statistically significant.

evidence.text: This disparity in pass rates between African-American and white test-takers on the written test was caused by Defendant’s use of the CEB.

extracted.value: The disparity in pass rates was caused by Defendant’s use of the CEB.

evidence.text: African-American applicants who passed the written test were invited for in-person interviews at a lower rate than white applicants who passed the written test.

extracted.value: African-American applicants who passed the written test were invited for interviews at a lower rate than white applicants who passed.

evidence.text: Approximately 32% of African-American applicants who were eligible for an interview failed to receive an invitation to interview, and approximately 14% of white applicants who were eligible for an interview failed to receive an invitation.

extracted.value: Approximately 32% of African-American eligible applicants failed to receive an invitation; 14% of white eligible applicants failed.

evidence.text: During this time period, the difference between the rates of African-American and white applicants who were invited for in-person interviews is statistically significant, with a standard deviation of more than three units.

extracted.value: The difference in invitation rates is statistically significant.

evidence.text: This disparity in the rates that African-American and white applicants were invited for interviews was caused by Defendant’s use of the CEB.

extracted.value: The disparity in invitation rates was caused by Defendant’s use of the CEB.

evidence.text: Defendant has hired at least sixteen (16) fewer African-American applicants as entry-level firefighters since 2015 than it otherwise would have had it used a non-discriminatory screening device.

extracted.value: Defendant has hired at least sixteen (16) fewer African-American applicants as entry-level firefighters since 2015.

evidence.text: The United States, through the United States Department of Justice, conducted an investigation of the policies and practices of Defendant with respect to its screening and hiring of applicants for the entry-level firefighter position at DFD and the discriminatory effect of such practices on African-American applicants.
